Graphical abstract B-cation titanium substituted potassium tantalates KTaxTi1-xO3 (x = 1.0; 0.8; 0.6; 0.5) materials were synthesized, characterized by XRD, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms, FTIR, DRS-UV–vis, TGA, H2-TPR and XPS to be used as catalysts for the selective oxidation of methyl phenyl sulfide. The non-substituted KTaO3 catalyst displays a total methyl phenyl sulfide conversion greater than 87% that increases with Ti substitution. The increases in the amount of titanium substituted decrease the crystallinity and the perovskite structure is not obtained, resulting in an amorphous material. The improvement in the conversion and selectivity towards the sulfone, is attributed to the slight loss of crystallinity that allows greater mobility of the lattice oxygen, essential in oxidation reactions and to the presence of TiO2 as segregated phases. These results obtained indicate that the substitution of B-cation generates physicochemical changes in the perovskite structure which enhances the oxidation properties of the catalysts. Keywords Perovskite Partial substitution Catalytic oxidation Methyl phenyl sulfide 1 Introduction Mixed oxide with perovskite structure has the general formula ABO3, where A is a rare earth, alkali or alkaline earth metal large cation, and B the smaller cation, generally a transition metal [1]. Mixed oxide has been extensively studied and successfully used due to their structural, physical and chemical properties such as ferroelectricity, magnetic and electronic properties [2]. Because of their well-known properties of oxygen mobility and large stabilization of transition metals in not usual oxidation states within their structure, a wide range of other applications have been reported, mainly catalytic [3–6]. One of the advantages of the perovskite structure is the possibility to synthesize multicomponent perovskites though the partial substitution of cations in positions A and/or B, with the general formula A1-xA’xB1-xB’xO3 to adjust their redox, physical-chemical and surface properties. Cationic substitutions in mixed oxides with perovskite structure are well explored and provide a large class of functional materials used for diverse applications depending on their specific composition [7–9]. The partial substitution of A by lower valence cation modify the electronic structure and produces oxygen vacancies which benefits oxidation reactions [1]. Likewise, the partial substitution of B with cations of similar size and lower oxidation state produces modifications in the physicochemical properties and generate oxygen vacancies, which play a prominent role in many redox reactions [10]. Nair and Abanades reported that the partial substitution on the cationic A and B sites of perovskite structured mixed oxides in the structure improves the catalyst performance modifying the redox properties and enhancing their stability [11]. The partial substitution of A-cation was investigated in order to improve the redox performance and results showed an improvement in the catalytic activity assigned to the change of the perovskite structure [12]. On the other hand, the B-cation substitution in perovskite structures presented a positive effect in the properties, enhancing thermal stability, resistance to sintering and improving the structural stability [13] It has been reported that B-cation substitution in perovskite structures improves the catalytic activity for many interesting applications. Da et al. [14] replaced the B-site by platinum in LaMn1-xPtxO3 perovskites, obtaining an increase of the oxygen vacancy concentration whereas an increase in the platinum doping amount, resulted in LaMn0.8Pt0.2O3 perovskite as the best catalyst for soot oxidation. For dry reforming of methane Dama et al. [15] synthesized zirconium alkali earth perovskite oxides and incorporated nickel in the B-site. In all cases, the substitution of x = 0.2 displays the large enhancement of the catalytic performance. Escalona et al. [16] synthesized and evaluated LaFe1-xCoxO3 perovskite in Fisher-Tropsch synthesis resulting the x = 0.2 substitution the best catalyst. Titanium has been reported to be suitable candidate as a B-cation partial substituted in perovskite structures due to generates an improvement in reducibility of the perovskites and in oxygen storage capacity and also promotes electronic and ionic conductivity, enhancing the catalytic performance [17,18]. In addition, titanium is probably the most widely metal used in sulfoxidation reactions [19,20]. Selective oxidation of sulfides in order to obtain the corresponding sulfoxides and/or sulfones is an important transformation in organic chemistry. Sulfoxides and sulfones are high-potential building blocks for useful compounds, such as antiulcer, antibacterial and antifungal, among others [21]. From an environmental and economic point of view, the use of hydrogen peroxide as oxidant is particularly useful due to the safety in storage and operation, cheapness, highly effective oxygen content and due to the fact that only generates water as by-product [4]. Without a metal catalyst, sulfide oxidation with hydrogen peroxide as oxidant require high temperatures and/or long reaction time [22]; so, optimizing catalysts and/or reaction systems allows to obtain highly selective oxidation of sulfide under mild reaction conditions. In the present work the synthesis and characterization of B-cation titanium substituted potassium tantalates KTaxTi1-xO3 (x = 1.0; 0.8; 0.6; 0.5) was reported to be used as high-efficient, reusable and selective catalysts for selective oxidation of methyl phenyl sulfide by using 30% aqueous hydrogen peroxide as oxidant under mild reaction conditions. In order to optimize the selectivity towards the sulfone, the effect of different reaction parameters (oxidant concentration, reaction temperature, catalyst amount, nature of the oxidant and the solvent, the leaching and reuses), and a kinetic study was carried out. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation KTaxTi1-xO3 (x = 1.0, 0.8, 0.6 and 0.5) powders were prepared by mixing an aqueous solution of potassium acetate (dissolved in the least amount of water) with a stoichiometric amount of TaCl5. The TaCl5 solution was previously dissolved in hydrogen peroxide in an ice water bath due to the reaction is highly exothermic. Then, citric acid was added under constant stirring. For the substituted titanium potassium tantalate, Ti(OC4H9)4 was added in the corresponding amount immediately after adding citric acid. A yellow pale solution was formed and heated at 80 °C for 4 h until a gel was formed, dried in a static furnace with vacuum at the same temperature and finally calcined at 600 °C for 10 h. (For amounts of reagents and a more detailed procedure of catalysts preparation see Supplementary Information). 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded with a Philips PW-30 diffractometer equipment with nickel filtered CuKα radiation, 20 mA and 40 kV in the high voltage source, and scanning angle between 20° and 70° 2Ɵ at a scanning rate of 2° per min. The phases were identified by comparing the diffraction patterns with the reference diffraction files in the EVA software. The specific surface area (SBET) of the solids was determined from the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at the liquid-nitrogen temperature obtained, through a TriStar II 3020 instrument. The solids were previously degassed at 100 °C for 2 h. The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of the solids were obtained using a Nicolet Magna-IR 550 spectrometer equipped with a quartz sample holder with KBr windows in the 400–4000 cm−1 wavenumber range. The diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS-UV–vis) of the materials were recorded using a UV–Vis JASCO V650 spectrophotometer to which a diffuse reflectance chamber with an integrating sphere of 50 mm diameter and internal Spectralon coating is attached, in the 200–800 nm wavelength range. The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements of the solids were carried out using a TG50 Shimadzu equipment. The thermogravimetric analyses were performed under nitrogen using a constant sample weight of 30 mg for all experiments and a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The studied temperature range was 20–700 °C. Temperature-Programmed Reduction (TPR) was carried out with a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2720 system equipped with a TCD detector. In the experiment 0.050 g of the sample was heated from ambient temperature to 700 °C at 10 °Cmin−1under a 5% H2/Ar flow at 50 mL min−1. X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using a Thermo Scientific X-ray K-Alpha photoelectron spectrometer. The binding energies were corrected by using C1 s peak of adventitious carbon at 284.8 eV as standard. A standard Gaussian/Lorentzian background were applied for peak fitting and calculating. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation In a typical experiment, a mixture of methyl phenyl sulfide (Sigma-Aldrich, 99% purity) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30% in water, Cicarelli) as oxidant and the amount of catalyst were added to a glass flask reactor containing the solvent used, such as: acetonitrile (Sintorgan, p.a.), methanol (Sintorgan, HPLC grade), ethanol (99.5%, Cicarelli, p.a.), 2-propanol (Sintorgan, HPLC grade), at different temperatures with magnetic stirring. All reagents were used without further purification. Several parameters such as: molar ratio of substrate/oxidant, reaction temperature, amount of catalyst, nature of the oxidant, nature of the solvent and reuses were evaluated. During the course of the experiments, samples were periodically withdrawn filtered using a Millipore syringe adapter (porosity 0.45 μm), analyzed, quantified quantified with heptane (Cicarelli, p.a.) as an internal standard (See Supplementary Information) and identified by comparison with the retention time with known standards by GC in a Perkin Elmer Clarus 500, equipped with a FID detector and capillary column ZB-1. The mass spectrometry GC-Mass (Shimadzu QP 5050 GC-17 A) with a HP-5 capillary column was used. Chromatographic peaks were identified by comparing their retention times and their mass spectra with those reported in NIST 2.0 commercial library. The conversion during reaction was calculated by using the method of area normalization employing response factors. The methyl phenyl sulfide conversion (%) was defined as the ratio of converted products to the initial moles (Eq. 1). (1) C o n v e r s i o n % = t o t a l m o l e s o f p r o d u c t s i n i t i a l m o l e s o f m e t h y l p h e n y l s u l f i d e × 100 To detect leaching, during the oxidation of methyl phenyl sulfide at 1 h of reaction the catalyst was completely separated by filtration and the reaction was continue for the total reaction time without catalyst. In order to evaluated the reusability of the catalysts, after the catalytic evaluation the catalyst was separated from the liquid phase, washed with acetonitrile, dried at 70 °C for 24 h and used in another reaction cycle under the same experimental conditions for five consecutive cycles. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 FTIR The FTIR spectra of the catalysts shown in Fig. 1 indicate great similarity in the titanium substituted potassium tantalates. The broadband at 3300 cm−1 is associated with the expansion of the OH bond of water, and the bands at 2930 and 2890 cm−1, to the CH bond [23]. Bands at 623 and 670 cm−1, characteristics of stretching vibrations for TaOTa and asymmetric stretching vibration for TaO bond can also be observed in the TaO6 octahedra, respectively [24], and the band at 920 cm−1 assigned to the stretching mode TaO bonds [25]. Increasing the substitution of tantalum by titanium it is observed an increase in the shoulder at 916 cm−1 corresponding to TiOTi bond is attributed to the presence of segregated TiO2. In addition, the intense broadband less than 850 cm−1 gets widen to a KTiO stretching vibration, indicative of the substitution of tantalate by titanium, incorporated intra-framework [26,27]. The presence of carbonates as segregated phases was confirmed by KTaO3 with the appearance of the two bands at 1400 and 1600 cm−1 associated to CO bond [28]. The increase in the intensity of the bands at 1400 and 1600 cm−1, is due to the overlap of the signal assigned to CO3 -2 with the signal assigned to nano-TiO2 and asymmetric stretching vibration of carboxyl groups coordinated with titanium. 3.1.2 XRD The XRD pattern shown in Fig. 2 a indicates large differences in the titanium substituted potassium tantalates. The sharp diffraction peaks for KTaO3 indicate the largest crystalline structure and a monotonic loss of crystallinity upon Ti substitution can be detected. For KTaO3 a cubic structure (JCPDS 35-1036) with presence of K2Ta2O6 (JCPDS 35-1464) and small peaks at 2Ɵ = 28°, 32° and 37.5° associated to K2CO3 (JCPDS 42–1467) [29] as segregates phases can be detected. With the increasing titanium substitution, the disappearance of the characteristic peaks of KTaO3 widens and weakens indicates a decrease of crystallinity. In the lowest replacement of Ta by Ti (x = 0.8), the cubic perovskite structure is maintained decreasing the intensity of the peaks. The absence of new diffraction peaks indicates that the substitution does not generate new segregated phases, however the signals assigned to K2CO3 as segregated species can still be detected, in line with FTIR results. For the larger Ti substitution (KTa0.6Ti0.4O3 and KTa0.5Ti0.5O3), a crystalline perovskite structure is no longer formed, the crystallinity is largely disappearing and new small peaks at 2Ɵ = 25.4, 31.8 and 48.5°, assigned to TiO2 anatase were detected (JCPDS 75-1582) [30] as segregated phase, in addition to the previously mentioned. The rutile TiO2 (JCPDS 21-1276) diffraction peaks (27.3° and 36.0°) were not detected. In addition, the shift of the 2 theta value increases slightly to larger values and is indicative of a KTaO3 lattice contraction. In line with previous reports, considering that the ionic radii of Ta5+ (0.064 nm) is greater than Ti4+ (0.060 nm), to maintain the electro neutrality, the contraction of the lattice should be accompanied by a change of the cations into higher oxidation state releasing electrons [14,31,32]. It has been reported that at higher titanium doping the catalysts require higher crystallization temperatures [17]. Therefore, the non-crystalline structure obtained for the samples with x = 0.6 and 0.5 is an expected result. The crystal sizes (Dc) of the perovskites estimated by the Scherrer’s equation using the diffraction signal at 29° are shown in Table 1 . The decrease in the crystal size with the increasing titanium substituted can be associated with the insertion of Ti+4 into the crystal lattice of KTaO3 [33]. 3.1.3 BET The nitrogen adsorption isotherms at 77 K shown in Fig. 3 indicate characteristics of non-porous materials that corresponds to type II (IUPAC classification) with no hysteresis loop [34]. This is an expected result, a characteristic of these materials attributed to no interconnectivity of the pores. The specific surface area values displayed in Table 1 are less than 15 m2 g−1; similar to those reported for perovskite-type structures prepared by citrate or sol-gel methods [1], and even bigger than LaNi1-xTixO3 perovskite catalysts [17]. Therefore, the similar and low surface area of the samples may not be the critical factor for the catalytic performance [33]. 3.1.4 DRS – UV–vis In order to evaluate the coordination geometry and chemical arrangement of the Ta and Ti species, the DRS-UV–vis spectra of the catalysts were carried out and shown in Fig. 4 a. The maximum band between 250–280 nm is attributed to Ta-O-Ta bond and with the Ti substitution the band gets wider. This behavior can be attributed to the superposition of the signal with the one assigned to electron transfer from the ligand–oxygen to an unoccupied orbital of the Ti4+ framework [35]. The spectra is also characterized by an intense band centered at 320 nm, corresponding to the electron transitions from the valence gap by 2p orbitals of oxygen to the conduction band of the empty Ti 3d orbitals [36]. The band-gap (Eg) values displayed in Table 1 determined by the Kubelka-Munk function, F(Roo) and by extrapolating a linear fit of the plot of F(Roo) = (1-R2)/2R as a function of energy from the DRS-UV–vis spectra shown in Fig. 4b [37]. The decrease of the Eg with Ti substitution compared to the non-substituted potassium tantalate is attributed to the localized gap states induced by reduced Ti3+ and oxygen vacancies [27]. Moreover, the charge transfer transitions from O 2p → Ta 5d occur at higher energy as it can be observed in Table 1. 3.1.5 TGA Fig. 5 shows the thermal gravimetric analysis and differential thermal analysis (TG/DTA) profiles of the catalysts from 30 to 700 °C. The first weight loss (between 30–150 °C) is assigned to the elimination of free and bound water, presented in DTA analysis with the characteristic two endothermic peaks lower than 5% in all cases. The weight loss at around 260 °C, accompanied by another endothermic event, is assigned to the decomposition of residual organic groups and segregated phases such as carboxylates [38], detected only for KTaO3 and KTa0.8Ti0.2O3, in concordance with XRD results. The weight loss between 400 °C and 600 °C is assigned to the decomposition of residual organic groups [4], and increases with the substitution of titanium. This behavior can be assigned to a superposition of the decomposition of residual organic groups and the corresponding to the transformation of an amorphous phase or mixture between anatase-brookite. Due to the synthesized tantalates were calcined at 600 °C, it is expected that the signal corresponds to TiO2 anatase, in concordance with XRD results. Moreover, in line with previous report, a decrease in the total weight with the increase of crystallinity of the perovskites [39] is detected, being 4% < 6% < 6.6% < 8.2% for KTaO3, KTa0.8Ti0.2O3, KTa0.6Ti0.4O3 and KTa0.5Ti0.5O3, respectively. 3.1.6 H2-TPR The H2-TPR profiles of the titanium substituted potassium tantalates are shown in Fig. 6 . The reduction profile of the KTaO3 presents two reduction peaks, similar to that of the perovskite structure reported by Li et al. [40]; the first one at 520 °C assigned to the formation of a perovskite deficiency in O2 and water [41], and the second one, at around 580 °C related to the K2CO3 decomposition [42]. For the titanium substituted tantalates a well-defined reduction peak that increases with the Ti substituted appears at near 600 °C, is assigned to a partial reduction of Ti4+ to Ti3+. For KTa0.8Ti0.2O3 and KTa0.6Ti0.4O3, a shift towards lower temperatures (590 and 580 °C, respectively) in H2-TPR profiles it has been reported about titanium is added to structure [43]. For KTa0.5Ti0.5O3, the signal was detected at ∼605 °C, this corroborates the presence of Ti as segregated phases. In line XRD results, the signal assigned to the formation of the non-stoichiometric perovskite structure is not detected. 3.1.7 XPS The C 1s, K 2p, Ta 4f, O 1s and Ti 2p core-level spectra of KTa0.8Ti0.2O3 are shown in Fig. 7 , and Table 2 details the respective binding energies (BE) of the core electrons of the elements of the perovskites catalysts. Owing to the charging effect through XPS analysis, the BE was corrected by adventitious carbon. For KTa0.8Ti0.2O3, the C1 s emission (Fig. 7a) presents two components: a BE of 284.8 eV assigned to adventitious carbon and a second one at 289 eV corresponding to carbonates species [44] as was identified by XRD and FTIR techniques. A similar spectra was obtained for all the perovskites (Table 2). The BE of K 2p (Fig. 7b) with the characteristic double signal at 292.9 eV and 295.6 eV does not present significant differences in all the studied materials, corresponding to K+1 forming part of the perovskite structure. A similar behavior was detected for the Ta 4f spectra (Fig. 7c) where the BE resulted similar in all cases; the signal of Ta 4f7/2 at 25.6 eV and the signal of Ta 4f5/2 at 27.4 eV is assigned to Ta+5. However, the integrated intensities of the Ta 4f signals decrease with the increase of Ti substitution. A similar behavior was reported by H. Taguchi et al. [45] O1 s spectra (Fig. 7e) show three signals: the lower BE assigned to O2− (526.9 eV) [Olatt], both OH- and carbonate (529 eV) [Oads], and the highest BE associated with adsorbed molecular water [46]. The signal of adsorbed water was also corroborated with FTIR and TG techniques, previously discussed. The Olatt is related to the redox ability of the perovskites and the Oads relates to the density of oxygen defect site in the perovskite influenced by surface oxygen vacancies [33]. Therefore, a larger ratio of Oads/Olatt indicates higher oxidation catalytic activity of the perovskites. As summarized in Table 2, while the amount of tantalum substituted increase, the value of Oads/Olatt increase with a maximum at x = 0.8 and the further decrease is closely related to the catalytic activity. These phenomena imply that the partial substitution of Ta by Ti can lead to the creation of oxygen defect sites. Considering that for x = 0.6 and x = 0.5 the perovskite structure was not completely obtained as previously mentioned, the values obtained are in concordance with the catalytic activity results. The Ti 4f spectra (Fig. 7d) presents the characteristic doublet of Ti+4. However, for KTa0.5Ti0.5O3 sample (Table 2) signals at 457.7 eV and 463.3 eV assigned to Ti+3 are also detected [47]. The presence of Ti+3 species not detected by XRD could be due to is highly dispersed as segregated phase. Their presence could be associated with the shift at higher temperatures of the reduction observed by TPR and the decrease of the Eg values determined by DRS-UV–vis, as was previously discussed. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation for KTaO3 3.2.1 Effect of oxidant concentration In order to optimize the experimental conditions for the evaluation of the catalysts, different parameters were evaluated using KTaO3 as catalyst. First, the effect of the oxidant amount varying the concentration of oxidant (H2O2) from 2 mmol to 4 mmol, and the results are presented in Fig. 8 . The effectiveness of H2O2 as active oxidant was corroborated due to almost no conversion that was achieved in its absence (∼1.5%). Whereas the H2O2 amount decreases, the final conversion of methyl phenyl sulfide declines as well as the methyl phenyl sulfone selectivity. This is attributed to the decrease of the effective oxidant concentration in the reaction medium. The final conversion increase from 55.5% to 87.4%, and the selectivity towards sulfone from 30.7% to 80.1%, when the concentration of oxidant increases from 2 mmol to 4 mmol respectively. When 6 mmol of H2O2 was used the methyl phenyl sulfide conversion and selectivity towards sulfone did not significant increased. This is due to a dilution of the reaction mixture by the presence of larger amount of water molecules in solution [48]. Therefore, form the experimental results it can be concluded that 4 mmol of H2O2 was the optimum oxidant amount and therefore, a two-step consecutive oxidation reaction mechanism of methyl phenyl sulfide can be proposed in Scheme 1 . This result is the expected behavior considering that the presence of a larger amount of oxidant molecules would benefit the second step of the proposed reaction mechanism and favors an over oxidation reaction. [49]. 3.2.2 Effect of reaction temperature In order to study the effect of the reaction temperature on the KTaO3 activity, the reaction was performed at five different temperatures and the results are presented in Fig. 9 . The final conversion was considerably increased when the reaction temperature increases from room temperature to 60 °C. An increase of the reaction temperature also improved the selectivity towards sulfone, in line with previous reports dealing with that at low temperatures the catalytic oxidation leads to sulfoxides and at large temperatures towards sulfones [19]. Although selectivity towards methyl phenyl sulfone slightly increases at 80 °C, the decrease in the total conversion can be attributed to the consumption of H2O2 in a parallel auto-decomposition reaction (reaction 1), favored at high temperature. (1) H2O2 → H2O + 0.5O2 3.2.3 Effect of catalyst amount The effect of the amount of catalyst was evaluated and the results are presented in Fig. 10 . For the non-catalytic reaction the total conversion of ∼10%, with selectivity of 52.7% towards sulfoxide and 47.3% towards sulfone can be attributed to the nature of the hydrogen peroxide, a weak electrophile and therefore a catalytic activation is required to access its full potential [50]. By adding 20 mg of catalyst, the final conversion was significantly increased reaching the highest conversion (87.4%) and the selectivity towards sulfone (80.1%). Hence, the catalyst not only improves total conversion, and also the selectivity towards sulfoxide. A further increase in the amount of catalyst caused no improvement in the final conversion; on the contrary, it decreased it. Bezaatpour et al. [51] reported that greater amounts of catalyst produce decomposing of H2O2, according to reaction (1). Considering that both H2O2 decomposition and methyl phenyl sulfide oxidation occur simultaneously, it decreased the availability of the oxidant explaining the decrease in conversion with the amount of catalyst. 3.2.4 Effect of the nature of the oxidant Catalytic oxidation reactions by employing several and strong oxidants [52–54] have been reported. Sulfides can be easily oxidized by a wide variety of oxidants; however some of these are not satisfactory for selectivity towards sulfones, toxicity, and expensive catalyst precursors. Due to environmental properties, hydroperoxides and alkyl hydroperoxides as cumene, cumylhydroperoxide, and tert-butyl are reported to be better oxidants [55]. In order to a better comparison with hydrogen peroxide, tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP, 70%wt in water, Aldrich) was assayed. It has been found that under similar experimental conditions, TBHP decreases the final conversion from 87.4% to 55.0%, and the methyl phenyl sulfone selectivity decreases from 80.1% to 63.7%, this behavior attributed to the steric hindrance of the bulky tert-butyl group in TBHP [55]. 3.2.5 Effect of the solvent In order to optimize the contact point where the catalyst, the oxidant and the reactant meet together, solvents with different polarities and proticities were studied. The selected solvents were water, methanol, 2-propanol, n-hexane, acetone and acetonitrile. When n-hexane and water were used as solvents it was not possible to obtain a homogeneous liquid phase and almost no conversion was obtained, 15.2% and 19.5% respectively. For the other solvents, the obtained trend follows the following order: acetonitrile (87.4%) > methanol (78.2%) > ethanol (61.9%) > 2-propanol (58.5%), likely due to the decreasing dielectric constant values: 37.5D, 32.6D, 24.3D and 18.7D, respectively. The higher conversion obtained in acetonitrile with respect to other solvents can be explained in terms of the polarity, higher dielectric constant value favoring the contact of the hydrophilic character of the perovskites, regardless the aproticity or proticity of the solvent. 3.2.6 Leaching With the aim of evaluating the leaching of the segregated phases detected by XRD during the oxidation of methyl phenyl sulfide a leaching test was performed. After one hour of reaction the catalyst was completely separated by filtration and the reaction was continued for the rest of the reaction time without catalyst. It was found that after the catalyst removal, the methyl phenyl sulfide conversion slightly increase (∼9.7%) as it is shown in Fig. 11 . This behavior could be due to the leaching of the active potassium carbonates segregated species [56] to the reaction medium, favored for the presence of a solvent with high dielectric constant solvent as acetonitrile. Nevertheless, the increase in conversion is not strongly significant when suggesting that the reaction proceeds homogeneously. The catalytic activity of alkaline carbonates has been reported by Salinas et al. [56]. They corroborated leaching of segregated carbonate species of alkaline earth titanates and the catalytic activity of these species in oxidation reactions. To corroborate this statement and the catalytic activity of potassium carbonate, a reaction was performed under the same reaction conditions employing 20 mg of K2CO3 as a catalyst. After 240 min of reaction, a final conversion of 48% was obtained. 3.2.7 Reuses The reuse in consecutive cycles of the catalyst was also carried out and the results are shown in Fig. 12 . A great stability due to 4 consecutive cycles was found and a decrease from 87.3% to 81.3% was detected. This behavior can be assigned to the unavoidable loss of catalyst during the process of filtration and leaching of the segregated species as was previously determined. The methyl phenyl sulfone selectivity remained over 75% in the four reuses confirming the stability and recyclable applicability for methyl phenyl sulfide oxidation in our experimental conditions. 3.3 Catalytic evaluation for KTaxTi1-xO3 (x = 1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.5) 3.3.1 Effect of Ti substitution Once the experimental reaction conditions for the selective catalytic oxidation of methyl phenyl sulfide to sulfone were optimized, the catalytic performance for the titanium substitution in the B-site KTaxTi1-xO3 (x = 1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.5) catalysts were carried out seeking the correlation with the modification of the physicochemical properties [10]. In Fig. 13 the conversion level upon reaction time is shown and in Table 2. Some of the kinetic results are also shown. It can be observed that after 4 h of reaction the non-catalytic reaction (Entry 5, Table 3 ) show the lowest conversion and selectivity towards the sulfone. The increase in both, conversion and selectivity in the catalytic reactions are clearly observed achieving a significant increases towards the sulfone > 60%. This important behavior, consequence of the synthesis method shows differences upon the substituted titanium loading. Taking into account the similar and low surface area and crystal size (Table 1) of KTaO3 and KTa0.8Ti0.2O3, and as was previously described that textural properties may not be the critical factor for the catalytic performance, the increases in the conversion and selectivity towards the sulfone can be attributed to modification in the redox properties associated to the titanium substitution. Although no Ti peaks were detected by XRD technique in KTa0.8Ti0.2O3 sample, the signal assigned to the reduction of Ti+4 to Ti+3 which generate a shift towards lower reduction temperatures assigned to Ti incorporated in the structure was detected by H2-TPR and corroborated by XPS technique. On the other hand, the catalytic results can be related to the crystalline structure associated to surface electron density that promotes electron transfer. Thus, the decrease in the crystallinity of the perovskite structure for KTa0.8Ti0.2O3 lower than KTaO3 can be associated to an increase in the oxygen mobility with large extent of weakly binding surface oxygen [57]. Additionally, the structural distortion on the BO6 octahedral upon B cation substitution favors the formation of oxygen vacancies. Conversely, with regard to the KTa0.6Ti0.4O3 and KTa0.5Ti0.5O3 (Entry 3 and 4, Table 3) catalysts, the conversion at 4 h of reaction caused no decrease of crystallinity. This behavior can be attributed to the absence of the perovskite structure at the selected calcination temperature (600 °C) in line with the previous Ni-containing ceria substituted perovskites [58]. Taking into account that for KTa0.6Ti0.4O3 and KTa0.5Ti0.5O3 the perovskite structure was not achieved, for these catalysts the catalytic activity must be assigned to the presence of TiO2 as a segregated phase, reported to be active in sulfide oxidation [59]. The turnover frequency (TOF) is a value that offers a straightforward way to compare data obtained. It is define as the number of revolutions of the catalytic cycle per unit time [51,60,61]. The turnover frequencies (TOF) calculated from Eq. 2 and shown in Table 3 also indicates some degree of dependence with the perovskite structure being the largest TOF value for KTa0.8Ti0.2O3. (2) T O F = m o l o f p r o d u c t m o l o f c a t a l y s t * t i m e The kinetic data of the titanium substituted potassium tantalates KTaxTi1-xO3 (x = 1.0; 0.8; 0.6; 0.5) at mild experimental reaction conditions with a friendly environmental oxidant can be pointed out. Although the obtained TOF values are quite similar to other previous reported catalysts [51,62], the highest selectivity towards sulfone is even higher [63,64] with sulfoxide as only by-product. Additionally, due to tantalum oxide easily reacts with other oxides to form mixed metal oxide phases with complex structure, tantalum oxide have been proposed as an efficient environmental catalysts for an industrial application, such as selective oxidation of hydrocarbons [65]. The satisfactory fit shown in Fig. 14 of the experimental data to a pseudo-first order reaction with a r2 values ranging larger than 0.9 allows the calculation of the pseudo-first order rate constant (k) and initial reaction rate (r0) values for methyl phenyl sulfide oxidation listed in Table 3. The similar k and r0 values for KTaxTi1-xO3 (x = 0.6 and 0.5) is in line with the previous discussion and the largest values for KTa0.8Ti0.2O3, support the enhancement of the catalytic performance in KTaO3 by a 20% of substitution of Ta by Ti. 4 Conclusion The catalytic activity of perovskites is then strongly dependent on the structure and their defects, which benefits the oxygen vacancies and lattice oxygen mobility. Titanium substituted potassium tantalates KTaxTi1-xO3 (x = 1.0; 0.8; 0.6; 0.5) prepared by the citrate method were characterized and used as catalysts for the selective methyl phenyl sulfide oxidation towards the sulfone. The improvement in the conversion and selectivity of the not substituted KTaO3 catalyst was achieved by replacing a 20% of substitution of Ta by Ti. This was confirmed by the shift towards higher diffraction angles, due to the decrease in crystallinity allowing a larger mobility of the lattice oxygen, an essential property in oxidation reactions. For greater Ti substitution (40 and 60%) catalysts calcined at 600 °C, the absence of the perovskite structure and appearance of TiO2 as segregated phases explain the catalytic behavior. The obtained results indicate that the substitution of B cation into a KTaO3 perovskite structure generates physicochemical changes which enhance the oxidation properties for 20% of substitution. coredata.dc:description: B-cation titanium substituted potassium tantalates KTaxTi1-xO3 (x = 1.0; 0.8; 0.6; 0.5) materials were synthesized, characterized by XRD, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms, FTIR, DRS-UV–vis, TGA, H2-TPR and XPS to be used as catalysts for the selective oxidation of methyl phenyl sulfide. The non-substituted KTaO3 catalyst displays a total methyl phenyl sulfide conversion greater than 87% that increases with Ti substitution. The increases in the amount of titanium substituted decrease the crystallinity and the perovskite structure is not obtained, resulting in an amorphous material. The improvement in the conversion and selectivity towards the sulfone, is attributed to the slight loss of crystallinity that allows greater mobility of the lattice oxygen, essential in oxidation reactions and to the presence of TiO2 as segregated phases. These results obtained indicate that the substitution of B-cation generates physicochemical changes in the perovskite structure which enhances the oxidation properties of the catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Titanium substituted potassium tantalates (KTaxTi1-xO3 x= 1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.5): Catalysts for the methyl phenyl sulfide oxidation
